moves.1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4 Nd: 5 Q-K2 QN-B3 [not 5.. KN-B3??? 6 N-Q6 mate] gives White nothing.
moves.5... Ngf6 6. Nxf6+: The Knight is not well-placed after 6 N-N3.
moves.6... Nxf6 7. Bc4 Bf5 8. Qe2 e6 9. Bg5 Bg: This super-refinement reduces all of White's attacking prospects. Petrosian has a knack for snuffing out such dreams twenty moves before they even enter his opponent's head!
moves.10. O-O-O Be7 11. h3: It might have been better to prevent further simplifications with 11 K-N1 N-Q4 12 B-B1! 0-0 13 B-Q3, etc.
moves.15. Qe4 b5: Now it's apparent why Black didn't castle long. He wants to drum up counter-play on the Q-side, which he couldn't do if his King lived there.
moves.16. Bd3 a5 17. c3: Already White has been thrown on a mild defensive.
moves.17... Qd6: 17... P-R5 would be met by 18 P-R3.
moves.18. g3: I thought he wanted to exchange Queens.
moves.18... b4 19. c4: Practically forced -- but now the QB Pawn is weak.
moves.19... Nf6 20. Qe5: After 20 Q-K2 O-O 21 B-B2 P-B4 White could easily end up with the bad Bishop.
Right after I made this move, Petrosian offered a draw. I was ready to accept, but Tal happened to be standing there at that moment, hovering anxiously, since a drawn result would practically clinch first place for him. [It would have put him up a full point over Fischer with just one round remaining -- LA] So I refused -- not because I thought White has anything in the position, but because I didn't want to give Tal the satisfaction!
moves.27... Rd6: Serendipity. Simply 27... NxB leads to a dead draw.
moves.28. Bxa8: This obvious capture shattered Petrosian, who apparently had been engrossed in analyzing the intricacies of 28 RxR KxR 29 RxP ch PxR 30 BxR K-B4 31 P-N3 N-Q2 32 K-B2 K-Q5 with an absolute bind on the dark squares.
moves.28... Rxd1+ 29. Kc2 Rf1: There's no turning back. If 29... R-Q1 30 RxRP wins.
moves.30. Rxa5 Rxf2+ 31. Kb3 Rh2 32. c5 Kd8: On 32... RxRP 33 R-R7 ch K-Q1 34 RxP RxP ch 35 KxP the Q-side Pawns hurtle toward a touchdown. The Bishop, since it can control both wings at once, is vastly superior to the Knight.
moves.33. Rb5: On 33 R-R7, 33... N-Q2! 34 P-B6 N-N3 holds.
moves.33... Rxh3: Now 333... N-Q2 is refuted by 34 P-B6.
moves.34. Rb8+ Kc7 35. Rb7+ Kc6: I suspect Petrosian saw White's reply, but wanted to be put out of his misery. 35... K-B1 36 RxBP RxP ch 37 KxP is futile.
moves.36. Kc4: Petrosian resigns. There's no defense to the discovered checkmate.
